title: R41370
content: Since the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010, Congress has focused on compensatory liability provisions in the Oil Pollution Act for responsible parties. This includes covering cleanup costs, economic damages, and addressing the deaths of 11 workers. The liability provisions aim to compensate those affected by the spill. The report discusses federal civil and criminal penalty provisions related to the Gulf spill and worker fatalities, separate from compensatory liability provisions under the Oil Pollution Act. Attorney General Eric Holder announced an investigation into the spill, emphasizing the punitive and deterrent nature of these penalties. The report discusses federal laws that may have been violated in relation to the Gulf spill, including provisions that extend beyond U.S. territorial sea. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act applies laws of the United States to the spill site, even though it is 50 miles off the coast of Louisiana. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act extends U.S. laws to the subsoil and seabed of the Outer Continental Shelf, including artificial islands and installations. The Deepwater Horizon spill location does not hinder the imposition of penalties under relevant statutes. Civil penalty ceilings are adjusted every four years to account for inflation. The Civil Penalty Inflation Adjustment Act requires adjustments to maximum civil penalties every four years to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. The Criminal Fine Improvements Act aims to increase fines for violations under the U.S. Code. The Criminal Fine Improvements Act (CFIA) aims to increase fines for violations under the U.S. Code. The maximum criminal fine imposed can be up to the greater of the specified amount in the offense law or alternative ceilings in the CFIA. For organizations, the penalty caps range from twice the gross gain or loss to $500,000 for felonies. Individuals face half the penalties of organizations. The CFIA does not apply in certain circumstances. The CFIA may not apply in certain circumstances, such as when a law explicitly exempts an offense from CFIA penalties. A district court has ruled that CFIA penalty caps do not override lower caps in the Endangered Species Act, as applying the CFIA cap would nullify the lower cap enacted after the CFIA. This ruling is based on the principle of statutory construction to give every word operative effect. The CFIA controls over other statutes that do not exempt themselves. One court's view on penalty caps under the Endangered Species Act may not be accepted by other courts. Civil administrative penalties under CWA section 311(b)(6) allow for Class I or Class II penalties up to $10,000 per violation. Civil administrative penalties under the Clean Water Act (CWA) section 311(b)(6) allow for Class I penalties up to $10,000 per violation and Class II penalties up to $16,000 per day of violation, with a maximum penalty of $125,000. CWA section 311(b)(7) outlines civil penalties for violating oil discharge bans or failing to carry out removal orders, with fines up to $37,500 per day of violation. The Clean Water Act (CWA) imposes civil administrative penalties for violations, with fines ranging from $10,000 to $37,500 per day of violation. Criminal penalties include fines of $2,500 to $50,000 per day of violation, imprisonment up to one year, or both. For repeat violations under the Clean Water Act, fines can range from $5,000 to $250,000 per day, with imprisonment up to six years. Organizations may face fines up to $1 million. Repeat false statements can result in fines up to $10,000 and imprisonment up to two years. For violations under the Clean Water Act, fines can be up to $20,000 per day, with imprisonment up to four years for repeat offenses. Civil penalties of up to $32,500 can be assessed for knowingly violating the Endangered Species Act, including the prohibition on the "take" of endangered species. The Endangered Species Act (ESA) imposes civil penalties of up to $650 for each violation, with criminal penalties of up to $50,000 in fines or one year imprisonment for knowing violations. The Marine Mammal Protection Act (MMPA) also allows for civil penalties for violations of its regulations. The Endangered Species Act (ESA) imposes civil penalties of up to $650 for each violation, with criminal penalties of up to $50,000 in fines or one year imprisonment for knowing violations. The Marine Mammal Protection Act (MMPA) allows for civil penalties of up to $11,000 for violations, with criminal penalties of up to $20,000 in fines or one year imprisonment. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act (MBTA) imposes fines of up to $15,000 or six months imprisonment for violations. The Gulf oil spill violated MBTA section 2, making it illegal to harm migratory birds. Oil companies have been convicted under the MBTA for bird deaths, even without specific targeting. OPA section 4303(a) imposes a civil penalty of up to $27,500 per day for non-compliance with financial responsibility requirements. The penalty amount considers the violation's nature, circumstances, and culpability. The agency has the authority to adjust, compromise, modify, or remit the penalty. The OCSLA allows for civil penalties of up to $35,000 per day for non-compliance with regulations. Criminal penalties can be imposed for willful violations, including making false statements. Violations of OCSLA regulations can result in fines up to $100,000, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both. Each day of violation constitutes a separate offense. Officers or agents of corporations involved in violations may also face fines or imprisonment. OSHA regulations impose civil penalties for violations, with fines ranging from $5,000 to $70,000 for willful and repeated violations. A "serious violation" incurs a penalty of up to $7,000, while non-serious violations may also result in fines. A "serious violation" is defined as a condition with a substantial probability of death or serious harm, unless the employer was unaware despite reasonable diligence. OSHA regulations impose civil penalties for violations, with fines ranging from $5,000 to $70,000 for willful and repeated violations. Failure to correct a violation may result in a civil penalty of up to $7,000 per day. Criminal penalties include fines up to $10,000 or imprisonment for willful violations causing death. False statements in documents can lead to fines up to $10,000 or imprisonment. Federal environmental crimes can result in fines up to $10,000 or imprisonment for up to six months. Prosecution often relies on provisions in Title 18 of the U.S. Code, such as aiding and abetting and conspiracy. These provisions allow for punishment of those who assist or conspire to commit federal offenses. Conspiracy to commit offenses or defraud the United States can result in fines or imprisonment for up to five years. Making false statements within federal jurisdiction can lead to similar penalties. Mail fraud and wire fraud can result in fines or imprisonment for up to 20 years. Wire fraud, 18 U.S.C. § 1343, involves transmitting fraudulent schemes via wire communication and can result in fines or imprisonment for up to 20 years. Obstruction of justice, 18 U.S.C. § 1512, includes intimidating or misleading others to influence testimony and can also lead to fines or imprisonment for up to 20 years. The U.S. Department of Justice filed a civil complaint related to the Gulf spill against multiple parties on December 15, 2010. The case was filed in the federal district court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, with potential penalties for defendants involved in the spill. The civil complaint filed by the U.S. Department of Justice related to the Gulf spill on December 15, 2010, seeks penalties for defendants involved in the spill, specifically for gross negligence or willful misconduct. The complaint does not specify a dollar amount for civil penalties but reserves the right to amend for further investigation into liabilities under various acts.
